Sir, letter r ? h am . d i r !, cted t0 refer to the Ministry’s letter ox the 3rd December, 1931 (No T X ? f thfe ^^iationi goverA'iAg the mportation livestock and raw animal products xnto India and to say that the Ministry desires to obtain similar information in regard to such imports into the States of Arabia other than the Kingdom ol the The Ministry would be glad if you would e Sood enough to obtain the required particulars iron the political Resident £>■& the Persian Gulf, The Under Secretary of State, economic Sc Overseas Dept., India Office, S . ti . 1.?, vihitehall plage, LGEDGN, S* W. 1, 3rd December, 1931, Sir I sm directed to acquaint you for the infor.13a.tia1 of the Secr<: tary of State for India, that the Ministry has had under reriew the existing arrangements for th© supply of information as to the regulations governing the importation of lirestook and raw animal products into countries abroad* In this connection I am to refer to India Office letter of the 14th July 1920, {S* 5713/20) informing the Ministry that the Government of India had b eon requested to send copies of the existing regulations in regard to the importation of livestock and of subsequent amandinent& or new regulations direct to the Ministry* Although as a result of this arrangement the Ministry has from time to time received communications from Local Governments of India, and has no definite grounds for supposing that the authorities in India have lost sight of the arrangement, yet it would seem to be advisable in view of the feet that the request was made over eleven years ago that it should again be brought to their notice. Moreover, the Ministry’s original request was limited to regulatioias regarding livestock (l*e* all live animals and birds), and the Ministry now desires to obtain in addition particulars of any regulations dealing with the importation/ The Under-Secretary of State, India Office, S* W. 1*intonation ct raw animal products (hides, bones, horns, hoofe, sausage casings* etc* ) and other mterials such as hay and straw packing* which have been made with a view to preverting the introduction of animal diseases. x x x j: x The Ministry would also be glad to learn whether there are any restrictions on dogs, cats, birds, and other pets accompanying travellers, and on poultry, pigeons and rabbits. I am, &e*, (Sgu.)'-'..-auAL^uu^ N < j.i ILLL;> j i ,,. l!a . };n . Circular, J v'' | V [ W 568/568/50“] ■ Iff 'b^ Foreign Office, March 23, 1932. Sir, Regulations governing Importation of Live-stock and Animal Products into Foreign Countries HIS Majesty's Government in the United Kingdom have had under ’ e '7 “' g al ' rangements for supply of information on the regulations governing the importation of live-stock and raw animal pi odnets into foreign countries. ‘2. In this connexion, I invite your attention to Lord Curzon’s circular despatch No. 208006/W/50 of the 26th July, 1920, conveying instructions to forward copies of the existing regulations governing the importation of live-stock into the country where you reside, as well as of any subsequent alterations or amendments thereto. 3. As regards a number of countries, however, no fresh information lias been received since 1920, or for some years, and, while it is recognised that there may have been no changes in the regulations, it appears desirable that the information at present available should be brought up to date. Moreover, the original request contained in the above- mentioned despatch was limited to the regulations dealing with the importation of live-stock. During recent years, however, similar regulations have been made by a number of foreign countries with a view to preventing the introduction of animal diseases by means of animal products (c.g., hides, bones, horns and hooves, &c., meat and meat products, sausage casings) and other materials such as hay and straw packing, and His Majesty’s Government in the United Kingdom, His Majesty’s Represenl^live^SI'tlVW at ^ ^A) 1 SECRO uoT, - —— -1 securing the infoimation ni q „ .. is intended to cover desirable to point out that ; i< <1111 | r „ er f arm stock, all kinds of live animals, and buds, and not onh tl e • ^ seeing that enquiries are constantly being received by the bo ^ in Great Britain and Northern Ireland in respect ot ^ and other pets accompanying travellers, and also in respect live-stock such as poultry, pigeons and rabbits. 5 . Further, I request that you will bear 111 mine it ''l'’ of forwarding information promptly, and as arranged in • - , >> telegram, in the case of the imposition or removal of prohibitions affecting animals or products from Great Britain, Northern Ireland and the Irish Free State. 6 . The full original texts of decrees or regulations should 111 all cases be transmitted as well as, in the case of all languages but Kremh, complete translations of all relevant matter. £ i* ~ ^ I F n yv v 1 F I i 011 Lord Curzon’s circular despatch on this subject. * 8 . With reference to paragraph 3 above, I also enclose herewith a copy (in duplicate) of a summary of the existing information in the possession of His Majesty s Government. I am, with great truth and regard, Sir, Your obedient Servant, JOHN SIMON * This paragraph is addressed only to His Majesty’s Representatives at Addis Ababa. Asuncion, Athens, Bangkok, Berne, Bogota, Brussels, Guatemala, Havana, Helsingfors, La Paz, Lima, Lisbon, Madrid, Monrovia, Oslo, Panama, Peking, Port-au-Prince, Prague^ Riga, Rome! Santiago, Santo Domingo, Stockholm, Tehran, Tokyo, Vienna.\ I Circular S Cl u' 5 v ' Foreign .Office, July *26, 1920. Sir, THE Ministry of Agriculture are anxious to obtain full and up-to-date information respecting the regulations governing the importation of live-stock into the country where you reside. 2. 1 request accordingly that you will send me as soon as possible four copies of the regulations in question, which need not be accom panied by translations, and that you will be careful to report in future any alterations or amendments in these regulations. Such alterations should be reported by despatch, except in the case of an absolute prohibition of importation, which should be reported by telegraph without delay. I am, with great truth and regard, Sir, Your most obedient, humble Servant, CURZON OF KEDLESTON. imuiiHn

location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: PZ 3067/32 'Regulations governing importation of live-stock and animal products into foreign countries'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence for this description (used for referencing) commences at f 6, and terminates at f 15, as it is part of a larger physical volume; these numbers are written in pencil, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled.

mods.abstract: Thefile contains correspondence regarding regulations governing imports oflivestock and animal products into Afghanistan, India, Muscat, Bahrain, Kuwaitand the Trucial States. The primary correspondents are: Secretary of State forForeign Affairs; Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries; William KerrFraser-Tytler, British Legation, Kabul; Political Resident, Persian Gulf.

name.namePart: Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food
Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs
